revised September 16, 1990) Activation of arene-chlorine bonds leading to o-bond formation of metal arene is a challenging problem from the standpoint of the wide availability of chloroarene compounds in organic syntheses. In the field of Pd chemistry, there have been two unique strategies for this bond activation in cooperation with other kinds of metals: the formation of Tr-arene Cr complexes [1] and the use of nickel mediators [2]. These studies inspired us to examine the use of a new type of Pd catalyst consisting of multiple monometal active centers in organic syntheses via Pd arene o-bond inter- mediates [3-5]. We have found that fine Pd particles supported on MgO showed high catalytic activity for Heck's phenylation of styrene with chlo- robenzene. This Pd MgO catalyst is much more active than the conventional Pd catalyst, e.g. Pd-C and Pd-AlgOa [6]. H \:=CH. / Ph Ph-CI Pd-MgO Na^COg. To Mg(OH)a (2.17 g) prepared by hydrolysis of Mg(N03)a 6HgO or Mg(OCHa)2, was added a mixture of Mg(NOa)2 6HaO (0.32 g) and HaO (3 ml), which was calcined at 600 C for 4 h to give MgO (4 m2 g-1). The MgO (1.50 g) was stirred in a benzene solution (4.5 ml) of Pd(acac)2 (10.4 mg) at room temperature for 1 h. The benzene was evaporated to dryness, and subsequent treatment with Hg at 60 C gave MgO-supported Pd catalyst (Pd surface area 268 m2 g~1 Pd) accompanied by a color change from pale yellow to grey. Pd MgO catalyst obtained gave a low yield of stilbene (turnover number 560). Using the Pd MgO catalyst prepared above, Heck's phenylation of styrene with chlorobenzene was carried out as a model reaction for the activation of arene chlorine bonds. The Pd catalyst exhibited high activity for stilbene formation; this turnover number with respect to g-atom Pd reached more than 1600 moles of stilbene at 150 C for 5 h. In comparison with the conventional heterogeneous Pd catalysts ofPd C, Pd AlaOs and Pd SiOg, this Pd MgO catalyst is much more active for stilbene formation. The reaction gave also biphenyl and benzene as minor products, derived from activation of the phenyl chlorine bond. The results are shown in Table 1. NagCOs was the most effective of the bases. It is interesting that use of other bases, e.g. amines, LigCOa and KgCOo, did not afford good results. From study of various solvents, MeOH was found to be the best. The specificity of MeOH might be due both to its good solubility for NagCOa and to its function as a hydrogen donor to remove chlorine on the Pd surface derived from side reactions of biphenyl and benzene formation. Addition of phosphines to this Pd MgO catalyst system strongly inhibited phenylation, while accelerating the activity of the Pd sepiolite catalyst. The sepiolite-Pd catalyst might act as a mono- meric Pd species, like the conventional homogeneous Pd catalysts. A most likely structure of the sepiolite Pd complex has been proposed to be (C3H5)Pd^-0-sepiolite. The Pd(II) species was reduced to Pd(0) species under the reaction conditions [7, 8]. Pd MgO catalyst in the absence of styrene at 150 C gave biphenyl* and methylbenzoate with ca. 950 and 150 turnover numbers for 5 h, respectively. Morphology of the Pd catalysts was examined by transmission electron microscopy techniques (TEM). The mean Pd particle sizes of Pd MgO, Pd-AlgOs, Pd-C and Pd-SiOg used here were 27, 35, 37 and 54 A, respectively. The shape of Pd particles on the MgO support is not globular, but nearly hemispherical, which reflects the strong affinity between Pd and MgO (Fig. 1). The high activity of the Pd MgO catalyst arises not only from its small Pd particles, but also from the intrinsic character of the MgO support. MgO, having a strong base character [9], may increase the electron density of a Pd center to promote the oxidative addition of chlorobenzene to the Pd [10]. A possible mechanism can be proposed for activation of chlorobenzene on the Pd MgO catalyst; one Pd forms a Tr-arene complex with chlorobenzene similar to the ir-arene Cr complex [I], and another Pd interacts with the chlorine atom of chlorobenzene; the Pd atom then inserts into the activated Ph Cl bond to form a o-phenyl Pd species [11, 12] which reacts with styrene to lead to stilbene formation. Reaction between two Ph Pd species gives biphenyl via a diphenyl Pd species [13]. Methylbenzoate might be formed by insertion of CO, generated from MeOH decomposition, into a phenyl Pd bond, followed by methanolysis. For biphenyl formation using Pd C, see also [6].
